StringWithMarkup.String: Concomitant use of corticosteroids increases the risk of severe tendon disorders (e.g., tendinitis, tendon rupture), especially in geriatric patients older than 60 years of age.

Reference: US Natl Inst Health; DailyMed. Current Medication Information for CIPRO (ciprofloxacin hydrochloride) tablet, film coated CIPRO (ciprofloxacin) kit (November 2011). Available from, as of February 28, 2012: https://dailymed.nlm.nih.gov/dailymed/lookup.cfm?setid=888dc7f9-ad9c-4c00-8d50-8ddfd9bd27c0

StringWithMarkup.String: Fluoroquinolones, including Cipro, are associated with an increased risk of tendinitis and tendon rupture in all ages. This risk is further increased in older patients usually over 60 years of age, in patients taking corticosteroid drugs, and in patients with kidney, heart or lung transplants.

Section.Description: In this section, "protein binding" refers to the degree to which medications attach to plasma proteins (i.e., proteins within the blood, such as human serum albumin, lipoprotein, glycoprotein and globulins). A drug's efficiency may be affected by the degree to which it binds to plasma proteins. The less bound a drug is, the more efficiently it can traverse cell membranes or diffuse.

This section provides information to evaluate the environmental impact of the chemical if it were released to the environment. The information may include data from toxicity tests performed on aquatic and/or terrestrial organisms, where available (e.g., acute or chronic aquatic toxicity data for fish, algae, and crustaceans; toxicity data on birds, bees, and plants).  This section also includes information on whether there is a potential for the chemical to persist or degrade in the environment either through biodegradation or other processes (such as oxidation or hydrolysis) as well as the concentration or amount of the chemical found in the environment (e.g., in plants, animals as well as in the atmosphere or water).
Excerpts about ecotoxicity of this compound, extracted from authoritative documents, such as journal articles, government reports, and reference books.

Reference: Halling-Sorensen B, et al; J Antimicrob Chemother 46 Suppl 1: 53-8; discussion 63-65 (2000)

StringWithMarkup.String: /AQUATIC SPECIES/ The effects of mecillinam, trimethoprim and ciprofloxacin, antibiotics used in the treatment of urinary tract infections, on the aquatic environment were assessed. Mecillinam and ciprofloxacin were both readily biodegradable (primary degradation) in activated sludge, whereas trimethoprim persisted. The toxicity of these antibiotics towards sludge bacteria, a green alga, a cyanobacterium, a crustacean and a fish were investigated; both mecillinam and ciprofloxacin were highly toxic to the cyanobacterium Microcystis aeruginosa (EC50 in the range 5-60 ug/L). Risk characterization for the aquatic environment was performed for the three compounds by calculating the predicted environmental concn (PEC) and the predicted no-effects concn (PNEC). A PEC/PNEC ratio of <1 indicates that, with the present pattern of use, no environmental risk is expected. PEC/PNEC ratios of <1 for present usage in Europe were found for mecillinam and trimethoprim whereas a PEC/PNEC ratio >1 was found for ciprofloxacin.

Reference: Ebert I et al; Environ Toxicol Chem 30 (12): 2786-92 (2011)

StringWithMarkup.String: /AQUATIC SPECIES/ The present study investigated the growth inhibition effect of the fluoroquinolone antibiotics enrofloxacin and ciprofloxacin on four photoautotrophic aquatic species: the freshwater microalga Desmodesmus subspicatus, the cyanobacterium Anabaena flosaquae, the monocotyledonous macrophyte Lemna minor, and the dicotyledonous macrophyte Myriophyllum spicatum. Both antibiotics, which act by inhibiting the bacterial DNA gyrase, demonstrated high toxicity to A. flosaquae and L. minor and moderate to slight toxicity to D. subspicatus and M. spicatum. The cyanobacterium was the most sensitive species with median effective concentration (EC50) values of 173 and 10.2 ug/L for enrofloxacin and ciprofloxacin, respectively. Lemna minor proved to be similarly sensitive, with EC50 values of 107 and 62.5 ug/L for enrofloxacin and ciprofloxacin, respectively. While enrofloxacin was more toxic to green algae, ciprofloxacin was more toxic to cyanobacteria. Calculated EC50s for D. subspicatus were 5,568 ug/L and >8,042 ug/L for enrofloxacin and ciprofloxacin, respectively. These data, as well as effect data from the literature, were compared with predicted and reported environmental concentrations. For two of the four species, a risk was identified at ciprofloxacin concentrations found in surface waters, sewage treatment plant influents and effluents, as well as in hospital effluents. For ciprofloxacin the results of the present study indicate a risk even at the predicted environmental concentration. In contrast, for enrofloxacin no risk was identified at predicted and measured concentrations.

Reference: Nie X et al; Environ Toxicol Chem 27 (1): 168-73 (2008)

StringWithMarkup.String: /AQUATIC SPECIES/ The effects of trichloroisocyanuric acid (TCCA) and ciprofloxacin (CPFX) on the freshwater alga Chlorella vulgaris were assessed by toxicity bioassays and by the values of biomarkers in phase I and phase II. The biomarkers included growth rate, concentration of chlorophyll a, activities of 7-ethoxyresorufin-O-dealkylases (EROD), glutathione S-transferase (GST), catalase (CAT), and total glutathione (GSH). Ciprofloxacin was a weaker growth inhibitor than TCCA but, at a concentration of >12.5 mg/L, decreased the growth of C. vulgaris. Concentration of chlorophyll a showed a similar trend. The 96-hr median effective concentration (EC50; i.e., 50% reduction in growth relative to the control) of CPFX was 20.6 mg/L. ... Ciprofloxacin and TCCA affected the phase I and phase II enzyme activities differently. On exposure to CPFX, both EROD and GSH decreased at low CPFX concentrations (<5.0 mg/L) and increased at high CPFX concentrations (>12.5 mg/L), and CAT and GST exhibited induction at low concentrations and inhibition at high concentrations. ...

Reference: Richards SM et al; Environ Toxicol Chem 23 (4): 1035-42 (2004)

StringWithMarkup.String: /FIELD STUDIES/ ...Outdoor aquatic microcosms /were exposed/ to combinations of ibuprofen (a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug), fluoxetine (a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor), and ciprofloxacin (a DNA gyrase-inhibiting antibiotic) at concentrations of 6, 10, and 10 ug/L, respectively (low treatment [LT]); 60, 100, and 100 ug/L, respectively (medium treatment [MT]); and 600, 1,000, and 1,000 ug/L, respectively (high treatment [HT]). ...Effects were observed in the MT and HT. Fish mortality occurred in the MT (<35 days) and in the HT (<4 days). Phytoplankton increased in abundance and decreased in diversity (number of taxa) in the HT, with consistent trends being observed in the MT and LT. Zooplankton also showed increased abundance and decreases in diversity in the HT, with consistent trends being observed in the MT. Multivariate analyses for zooplankton and phytoplankton suggested interactions between these communities. Lemna gibba and Myriophyllum spp. showed mortality in the HT; growth of L. gibba was also reduced in the MT. Bacterial abundance did not change in the HT. All responses were observed at concentrations well below the equivalent pharmacologically active concentrations in mammals. Although the present data do not suggest that ibuprofen, fluoxetine, and ciprofloxacin are individually causing adverse effects in surface-water environments, questions remain about additive responses from mixtures.

Section.Description: This section summarizes the environmental fate/exposure of this chemical, including the natural and artificial sources of the chemical as a pollutant, its environmental fate, biodegradation, abiotic degradation, bioconcentration, etc.

StringWithMarkup.String: Ciprofloxacin's production and use as an antibiotic may result in its release to the environment through various waste streams. If released to air, an estimated vapor pressure of 2.8X10-13 mm Hg at 25 °C indicates ciprofloxacin will exist solely in the particulate phase in the atmosphere. Particulate-phase ciprofloxacin will be removed from the atmosphere by wet or dry deposition. Ciprofloxacin in aqueous solution is susceptible to photodegradation, suggesting that the compound may be susceptible to direct photolysis by sunlight. If released to soil, ciprofloxacin is expected to be immobile based upon a Koc of 61,000. The pKa values are 6.09 for the carboxylic acid group and 8.74 for the nitrogen on the piperazinyl ring; at pHs greater than 6.09, the acid will be primarily dissociated and at pHs less than 8.74, the nitrogen will be primarily protonated. Volatilization from moist soil is not expected because the compound exists as an ion and ions do not volatilize. Ciprofloxacin may not volatilize from dry soil surfaces based upon its vapor pressure. Using the OECD closed bottle biodegradation study, 0% degradation over a 40-day incubation period was observed, indicating that biodegradation is not an important environmental fate process in soil and water. If released into water, ciprofloxacin is expected to adsorb to suspended solids and sediment based upon the Koc. Ciprofloxacin is an amphotertic compound and therefore, volatilization from water and moist soil surfaces is not expected to be an important fate process. An estimated BCF of 3 suggests the potential for bioconcentration in aquatic organisms is low. Aqueous ciprofloxacin solutions are susceptible to photolysis in sunlight. Occupational exposure to ciprofloxacin may occur through inhalation and dermal contact with this compound at workplaces where ciprofloxacin is produced or used. Monitoring data indicate that the general population may be exposed to ciprofloxacin via ingestion and dermal contact with contaminated water. Exposure to ciprofloxacin among the general population will occur to those administered the drug. (SRC)

Section.Description: Pollutants are emitted from a range of natural and man-made (artificial) sources.  This section provides information on the artificial sources of the compound as a pollutant.

Reference: (1) O'Neil MJ, ed; The Merck Index. 14th ed., Whitehouse Station, NJ: Merck and Co., Inc., p. 386 (2006)

StringWithMarkup.String: Ciprofloxacin's production and use as an antibiotic(1) may result in its release to the environment through various waste streams(SRC).

Section.Description: Environmental fate describes where this chemical goes when it gets out into the environment and how it might be chemically transformed in that process.  This section may provide information on multiple types of environmental fates of the chemical (e.g., aquatic fate, terrestrial fate, and atmospheric fate).

Reference: (1) Swann RL et al; Res Rev 85: 17-28 (1983)
(2) Nowara A et al; J Agric Food Chem 45: 1459-1463 (1997)
(3) Torniainen K et al; Int J Pharm 132: 53-61 (1996)
(4) Lyman WJ; p. 31 in Environmental Exposure From Chemicals Vol I, Neely WB, Blau GE, eds, Boca Raton, FL: CRC Press (1985)
(5) Al-Ahmad A et al; Arch Environ Contam Toxicol 37: 158-163 (1999)

StringWithMarkup.String: TERRESTRIAL FATE: Based on a classification scheme(1), a Koc value of 61,000(2), indicates that ciprofloxacin is expected to be immobile in soil(SRC). The pKa values are 6.09 for the carboxylic acid group and 8.74 for the nitrogen on the piperazinyl ring(3); at pHs greater than 6.09, the acid will be primarily dissociated and at pHs less than 8.74, the nitrogen will be primarily protonated. Volatilization from moist soil is not expected because the compound exists as an ion and ions do not volatilize. Ciprofloxacin is not expected to volatilize from dry soil surfaces(SRC) based upon an estimated vapor pressure of 2.8X10-13 mm Hg at 25 °C(SRC), determined from a fragment constant method(4). Using the OECD closed bottle biodegradation study, 0% degradation over a 40-day incubation period was observed(5), indicating that biodegradation is not an important environmental fate process in soil(SRC).

Reference: (1) Swann RL et al; Res Rev 85: 17-28 (1983)
(2) Nowara A et al; J Agric Food Chem 45: 1459-1463 (1997)
(3) Torniainen K et al; Int J Pharm 132: 53-61 (1996)
(4) Franke C et al; Chemosphere 29: 1501-14 (1994)
(5) Takacs-Novak,K et al; Int J Pharm 79: 89-96 (1992)
(6) US EPA; Estimation Program Interface (EPI) Suite. Ver. 4.1. Jan, 2010. Available from, as of Jan 31, 2012: https://www.epa.gov/oppt/exposure/pubs/episuitedl.htm
(7) Al-Ahmad A et al; Arch Environ Contam Toxicol 37: 158-163 (1999)

StringWithMarkup.String: AQUATIC FATE: Based on a classification scheme(1), a Koc value of 61,000(2) indicates that ciprofloxacin is expected to adsorb to suspended solids and sediment(SRC). The pKa values are 6.09 for the carboxylic acid group and 8.74 for the nitrogen on the piperazinyl ring(3); at pHs greater than 6.09, the acid will be primarily dissociated and at pHs less than 8.74, the nitrogen will be primarily protonated(SRC); therefore, volatilization from water and moist soil surfaces is not expected to be an important fate process. According to a classification scheme(4), an estimated BCF of 3(SRC), from its log Kow of 0.28(5) and a regression-derived equation(6), suggests the potential for bioconcentration in aquatic organisms is low(SRC). Using the OECD closed bottle biodegradation study, 0% degradation over a 40-day incubation period was observed(7), indicating that biodegradation is not an important environmental fate process in water(SRC).

Reference: (1) Bidleman TF; Environ Sci Technol 22: 361-367 (1988)
(2) Lyman WJ; p. 31 in Environmental Exposure From Chemicals Vol I, Neely WB, Blau GE, eds, Boca Raton, FL: CRC Press (1985)
(3) Burhenne J et al; Chemosphere 38: 1279-1286 (1999)

StringWithMarkup.String: ATMOSPHERIC FATE: According to a model of gas/particle partitioning of semivolatile organic compounds in the atmosphere(1), ciprofloxacin, which has an estimated vapor pressure of 2.8X10-13 mm Hg at 25 °C(SRC), determined from a fragment constant method(2), is expected to exist solely in the particulate phase in the ambient atmosphere. Particulate-phase ciprofloxacin may be removed from the air by wet or dry deposition(SRC). Ciprofloxacin in aqueous solution is susceptible to photodegradation(3), suggesting that the compound may be susceptible to direct photolysis by sunlight(SRC).

Section.Description: This section provides information on environmental biodegradation for this compound. Biodegradation is the breakdown of organic matter by microorganisms, such as bacteria and fungi.  An important measure of biodegradability of wastewater is the biochemical oxygen demand (BOD), which is the amount of dissolved oxygen (DO) needed (i.e. demanded) by aerobic biological organisms to break down organic material present in a given water sample at certain temperature over a specific time period.

Reference: (1) Al-Ahmad A et al; Arch Environ Contam Toxicol 37: 158-163 (1999)
(2) Li B, Zhang T; Environ Sci Technol 44: 3468-3473 (2010)

StringWithMarkup.String: AEROBIC: Using the OECD Closed Bottle Test protocol and an inoculum from an STP accepting hospital wastewater effluent, a test concentration of 3.5 ug/mL ciprofloxacin exhibited 0% biodegradation after both 28 and 40-day incubation periods(1). Ciprofloxacin, present at 100 ug/L, was not biodegraded in 6 hours using Hong Kong wastewater treatment plant freshwater sewage inoculum (Stanley plant: freshwater sewage; hydraulic retention time 17 hrs; sewage retention time 7 days) in a batch test. Adsorption was the dominant process (adsorption elimination efficiency of 90.8%)(2). Using a saltwater sewage inoculum (Shatin plant: saline sewage; hydraulic retention time 10 hrs; sewage retention time 12 hrs), ciprofloxacin, present at 100 ug/L, was 32.2% biodegraded following an initial adsorption-dominant period of 15 minutes (adsorption elimination efficiency of 52.8%)(2).

Reference: (1) Golet EM et al; Environ Sci Technol 37: 3243-3249 (2003)

StringWithMarkup.String: Using a mass flow analysis approach, cirpofloxacin, at an average concentration of 427 ng/L in raw sewage entering an urban wastewater treatment plant (Zurish-Werdhoelzli, Switzerland) was removed (tertiary effluent concentration of 71 ng/L) mainly due to sorption on sewage sludge. A sludge-wastewater partition coefficient (log Kd 4.3) was calculated in activated sludge reactors with a hydraulic residence time of about 8 hrs. Removal under methanogenic operations, biodegradation did not occur. Ciprofloxin was present on average at a concentration of 3.1 mg/kg in the anaerobically digested sludge which was applied to an experimental field in Reckenholz near Zurich. The compound proved persistent in soil (54% sand, 21% silt, 18% clay, 4% organic matter, pH 6.7; cation exchange capacity 28 mequiv/100 g) and exhibiting limited mobility(1).

Section.Description: Abiotic degradation is a process by which a chemical substance is broken down into smaller molecules by non-biotic means (e.g., hydrolysis, photolysis, and oxidation).

Reference: (1) Lyman WJ et al; Handbook of Chemical Property Estimation Methods. Washington, DC: Amer Chem Soc pp. 7-4, 7-5 (1990)
(2) Torniainen K et al; Int J Pharm 132: 53-61 (1996)
(3) Burhenne J et al; Chemosphere 38: 1279-1286 (1999)
(4) Vasconcelos TG et al; Chemosphere 76: 487-493 (2009)
(5) Belden JB et al; Chemosphere 66: 1390-1395 (2007)

StringWithMarkup.String: Ciprofloxacin is not expected to undergo hydrolysis in the environment due to the lack of functional groups that hydrolyze under environmental conditions(1). In photodegradation studies using aqueous solutions of ciprofloxacin (at pHs ranging from 4.0 to 10.6) irradiated with a high pressure mercury lamp at 313 nm, ciprofloxacin had the following initial half-lives: 22 min (pH 8.6), 40 min (pH 6.0), 55 min (pH 4.0), 104 min (pH 5) and 200 min (pH 10.6); the variation with pH was explained by the amphoteric nature of ciprofloxacin which has pKa values of 6.09 (for the carboxylic acid) and 8.74 (for the nitrogen on the piperazinyl ring); at pH 5.0, photolysis half-lives varied with concentration as follows: 1.7 hr (0.00005 M), 7.6 hr (0.00025 M) and 15 hr (0.0005 M). Photodegradation in natural sunlight was much slower; exposure of aqueous solutions (pH 5.0) to daylight for 15 days in Finland (March 1995) resulted in ciprofloxacin losses of only 2-15.7%(2). The main degradation product of ciprofloxacin photolysis is a compound that replaces the entire piperazinyl ring with an amino (NH2) group(3). Under alkaline conditions (pH 9) at 30 °C, ciprofloxacin at 0.1 mg/L in aquatic solution was subjected to quartz lamp light source; a first order photodegradation half-lives of 0.77, 0.15, and 0.38 hours was observed at pH 5 (cation), pH 7 (zwitterion), and pH 9 (anion), respectively. Photoproducts include 7-[(2-aminoethyl)amino-6-fluoroquinoline(4). Ciprofloxacin in aqueous solution exhibited a photodegradation half-life of 2.9 hours. The addition of fine particulate organic matter to the solution slowed the rate of photodegradation, resulting in a half-life of 7.4 hours(5).

Section.Description: This section provides information on environmental bioconcentration for this compound.  Bioconcentration is the accumulation of a chemical in or on an organism when the source of chemical is solely water. Bioconcentration is a term that was created for use in the field of aquatic toxicology. Bioconcentration can also be defined as the process by which a chemical concentration in an aquatic organism exceeds that in water as a result of exposure to a waterborne chemical.

Reference: (1) Takacs-Novak,K et al; Int J Pharm 79: 89-96 (1992)
(2) US EPA; Estimation Program Interface (EPI) Suite. Ver. 4.1. Jan, 2010. Available from, as of Jan 31, 2012: https://www.epa.gov/oppt/exposure/pubs/episuitedl.htm
(3) Franke C et al; Chemosphere 29: 1501-14 (1994)

StringWithMarkup.String: An estimated BCF of 3 was calculated in fish for ciprofloxacin(SRC), using a log Kow of 0.28(1) and a regression-derived equation(2). According to a classification scheme(3), this BCF suggests the potential for bioconcentration in aquatic organisms is low(SRC).

Reference: (1) Lillenberg M et al; Agronomy Res 8: 807-14 (2010). Available from, as of Aug 6, 2012: https://www.eau.ee/~agronomy/volo81/p8105.pdf
(2) Migliore L et al; Chemosphere 52: 1233-44 (2003)

StringWithMarkup.String: Ciprofloxacin has been shown to accumulate in barley and cucumber when experimentally grown in soil augmented with this compound at nominal concentrations of 500 ug/g and in lettuce in soil augmented at concentrations of 10-500 ug/g(1). Various crop plants containing high concentrations of enrofloxacin (taken up from sludge-amended soil) readily metabolize this compound into cirpofloxaxin(2).

Section.Description: Sorption to soils and sediments is an important factor on the transport and fate of organic contaminants in the environment.  The soil/water adsorption coefficient, also known as solid-water distribution coefficient (Kd), measures the amount of chemical substance adsorbed onto soil per amount of water.  Since adsorption occurs predominantly by partition into the soil organic matter, it is more useful to normalize the Kd value to the organic carbon content of a soil and express the distribution coefficient in Koc (organic carbon normalized distribution coefficient).  The greater the Kd (or Koc) value, the less likely a chemical will leach or contribute to runoff.  A very high value means it is strongly adsorbed onto soil and organic matter and does not move throughout the soil.

Reference: (1) Nowara A et al; J Agric Food Chem 45: 1459-1463 (1997)
(2) Swann RL et al; Res Rev 85: 17-28 (1983)
(3) Torniainen K et al; Int J Pharm 132: 53-61 (1996)
(4) Trivedi P, Vasudevan D; Environ Sci Technol 41: 3153-3158 (2007)
(5) Conkle JL et al; Chemosphere 80: 1353-1359 (2010)

StringWithMarkup.String: A Koc of 61,000 was determined in batch sorption studies using a German soil(1). According to a classification scheme(2), this Koc value suggests that ciprofloxacin is expected to be immobile in soil. Ciprofloxacin is an amphoteric compound with pKa values of 6.09 for the carboxylic acid group and 8.74 for the nitrogen on the piperazinyl ring(3); at pHs greater than 6.09, the acid will be primarily dissociated and at pHs less than 8.74, the nitrogen will be primarily protonated(SRC); therefore, ciprofloxacin will have an ionic charge at any environmental pH(SRC); sorption of ciprofloxacin and other fluoroquinolone carboxylic acid compounds appears to occur through ionic binding(1), and the high sorption to soil prevents leaching into ground or surface waters(1). It has been shown that the presence of dissolved and surface bound ferric species induced deprotonation of the carboxylic group at pH values less than the pKa of 6.09(4). Cirpofloxacin, added at 20, 30, 40, 50, 60, and 80 g/kg exhibited Kd values of 4844, 3587, 2798, 1835, 1338, and 834, respectively, using a Louisiana wastewater treatment wetland soil, Bayou Castine. These values correspond to 89.2, 85.2, 80.5, 75.6, 69.0, and 62.3% sorption, respectively(5).

Section.Description: Volatilization of chemicals from water/soil is the transfer of the chemical as a gas through the water-air or soil-air interface under environmental conditions

Reference: (1) Torniainen K et al; Int J Pharm 132: 53-61 (1996)
(2) Lyman WJ; p. 31 in Environmental Exposure From Chemicals Vol I, Neely WB, Blau GE, eds, Boca Raton, FL: CRC Press (1985)

StringWithMarkup.String: Ciprofloxacin is an amphoteric compound with pKa values of 6.09 for the carboxylic acid group and 8.74 for the nitrogen on the piperazinyl ring(1); at pHs greater than 6.09, the acid will be primarily dissociated and at pHs less than 8.74, the nitrogen will be primarily protonated(SRC); therefore, volatilization from water and moist soil surfaces is not expected to be an important fate process(SRC). Ciprofloxacin is not expected to volatilize from dry soil surfaces(SRC) based upon an estimated vapor pressure of 2.8X10-13 mm Hg(SRC), determined from a fragment constant method(2).

Section.Description: Concentrations of this chemical in water in various stages of hydrologic cycle (e.g., drinking water, ground water, surface water, and rain/snow).

Reference: (1) Hileman B; Troubled waters. EPA, USGS try to quantify prevalence, risks of compounds from drugs, personal care products. C&EN. Dec 3, 2001. 79: 31-33 (2001)
(2) Barnes KK et al; Ground Water Monit Remed 24: 119-126 (2004)

StringWithMarkup.String: GROUNDWATER: Ciprofloxacin is one of the drugs earmarked by the US Geological Survey Toxic Substances Hydrology Program's national reconnaissance of pharmaceuticals and other organic waste contaminants in groundwater(1). It was tested for, not detected in five leachate plume samples from downgradient of the Norman, OK municipal landfill collected on September 6, 2000; reporting limit = 0.02 ug/L(2).

Reference: (1) Stackleberg PE et al; Sci Total Environ 329: 99-113 (2004)

StringWithMarkup.String: DRINKING WATER: Ciprofloxacin was tested for but not detected in finished drinking water from a facility located in a heavily populated, highly urbanized US drainage basin; reporting level = 0.02. It was not detected in associated stream and raw water samples(1).

Reference: (1) Kolpin DW et al; Environ Sci Technol 36: 1202-11 (2002)
(2) Kolpin DW et al; Sci Total Environ 348: 119-130 (2004)
(3) Klecka G et al; Rev Environ Contam Toxicol 207: 1-93 (2010)
(4) Haggard BE et al; J Environ Qual 35: 1078-1087 (2006)
(5) Conley JM et al; Chemosphere 73: 1178-1187 (2008)
(6) Luo Y et al; Environ Sci Technol 45: 1827-1833 (2011)
(7) Tamtam F et al; Sci Total Environ 393: 84-95 (2008)

StringWithMarkup.String: SURFACE WATER: In a survey conducted by the United States Geological Survey, ciprofloxacin was detected at a maximum concentration of 0.03 ug/L (0.02 ug/L median concentration, 0.02 ug/L reporting level) at a 2.6% frequency in 115 submitted water samples from a network of 139 US stream sampling sites across 30 states during 1999-2000(1,2). Analysis of Great Lakes water sample data indicate that ciprofloxacin has been detected at a mean concentration of 0.0158 ug/L(3). Ciprofloxacin exhibited a 10% frequency (0.027 and 0.039 ug/L minimum and maximum, respectively) in samples from 18 sites on seven selected north-central (forested) and northwestern (urban/suburban) streams in Arkansas sampled during March, April, and August 2004; reported concentrations(4). Ciprofloxacin was detected in 10.2% of 120 water samples collected seasonally from Upper Tennessee River from the confluence of the Holston and French Broad Rivers to the beginning of the Tennessee River Gorge between December 2006 and October 2007 at concentrations ranging from 4.7 to 54.2 ng/L, average/median 6.9 ng/L(5). The average ciprofloxacin concentrations in the water column mainstream of the Haihe River, northern China were 1.1X10+2 and 1.3X10+2 ng/L in August and December 2009, respectively(6). Ciprofloxacin exhibited detection frequencies of 0% in samples from 5 locations (Poses, La Bouille, Caudebec, Tancarville, and Honfleur) along the Seine River, France, sampled from January to June 2006; reported maximum concentrations were <10 ng/L, for all sites(7).

Section.Description: Concentration of this compound in effluent.  Effluent is wastewater (treated or untreated) discharged into surface waters from a treatment plant, sewer, or industrial outfall.

Reference: (1) Alvarez DA et al; Chemosphere 61: 610-622 (2005)
(2) Karthikeyan KG, Meyer MT; Sci Total Environ 361: 196-207 (2006)
(3) Miao X-S et al; Environ Sci Technol 38: 3533-3541 (2004)

StringWithMarkup.String: Cirpofloxacin concentrations were <10 ng/L at 2 sampling sites on the Assunpink Creek, Trenton, NJ, a tributary to the Delaware River. Site one is the outflow of a wastewater treatment plant; site 2 was approximately 2 miles downstream(1). Average concentrations of 0.31 and 0.31 ug/L have been reported for influent and effluent respectively, of wastewater treatment plants sampled in Wisconsin(2). The compound was detected in treated wastewater effluents from 8 treatment plants in 5 Canadian cities at a median concentration of 0.118 ug/L (maximum of 0.400 ug/L); sampling was conducted in 2002(3).

Reference: (1) Alder AC et al; Amer Chem Soc, Div Environ Chem, Preprint Ext Abstr, 219th ACS Nat Meet, Vol 40, p 103-4 (2000)
(2) Hartmann A et al; Environ Toxicol Chem 17: 377-382 (1998)
(3) Hartmann A et al; Arch Environ Contam Toxicol 36: 115-119 (1999)
(4) Andreozzi R et al; Chemosphere 50: 1319-1330 (2003)
(5) Sim W et al; Chemosphere 82(2): 179-186 (2011)
(6) Castiglioni S et al; Environ Sci Technol 40: 357-363 (2006)

StringWithMarkup.String: Concentrations of 250 to 370 ng/L ciprofloxacin were detected (detection limit of 50 ng/L) in 24-hr composite samples collected from the primary effluent of a municipal waste treatment plant in Zurich, Switzerland(1); 24-hr composite samples of the secondary effluent contained ciprofloxacin concentration of 70-80 ng/L ndicating that 70-80% is eliminated during the activated sludge treatment with residual amounts being discharged to ambient water(1). Ciprofloxacin concentrations of 3-87 ug/L were detected (detection limit 0.5 ug/L) in wastewater samples collected from the main sewer of a hospital in Switzerland(2). Ciprofloxacin concentrations of 0.7-124.5 ug/L (median of 3.1 ug/L) were detected (detection limit 0.5 ug/L) in all 24 wastewater samples collected from the main sewers of five hospital in southern Germany between April 1992 and Nov 1994(3). The compound was reported in sewage treatment plant effluents at concentrations of 0.06, 0.07, 0.04-0.07, 0.03, and 0.05-0.11 ug/L sampled in France, Greece, Italy, Sweden, and Germany and Switzerland, respectively(4). Mean ciprofloxacin concentrations in wastewater effluent from 12 municipal wastewater treatment plants, 4 livestock farms, 4 hospitals and 4 pharmaceutical manufactures collected between June and September 2008 were 0.0.728, 0.142, 1.98, and 8.71 ug/L, respectively. Frequency of detections were as follows (influent/effluent): municipal wastewater treatment plants 3 of 30/3 of 34; livestock farms: 0 of 8; 1 of 8; hospitals: 4 of 12/1 of 8; pharmaceutical manufactures: 5 of 8; 2 of 8. Sampling sites were located near major river basins of Korea(5). Ciprofloxacin loads ranged from 120-507 mg/day/1000 inhabitants (influent) to 37-271 mg/day/1000 inhabitants (effluent) in a study 6 sewage treatment plants from different regions of Italy(6).

StringWithMarkup.String: Ciprofloxacin hydrochloride is rapidly and well absorbed from the GI tract following oral administration, and undergoes minimal first-pass metabolism. The oral bioavailability of ciprofloxacin administered as conventional tablets is 50-85% in healthy, fasting adults, and peak serum concentrations of the drug generally are attained within 0.5-2.3 hours. Peak serum concentrations and area under the serum concentration-time curve (AUC) increase in proportion to the dose over the oral dosage range of 250-1000 mg and are unaffected by gender. Following oral administration of a single 250-, 500-, 750-, or 1000-mg dose of ciprofloxacin as conventional tablets or oral suspension in healthy, fasting adults, peak serum concentrations average 0.76-1.5, 1.6-2.9, 2.5-4.3, or 3.4-5.4 ug/mL, respectively; serum concentrations 12 hours after the dose average 0.1, 0.2, 0.4, or 0.6 ug/mL, respectively. In adults, oral administration of 500 mg of ciprofloxacin as conventional tablets every 12 hours results in mean peak or trough serum concentrations at steady-state of 2.97 or 0.2 ug/mL, respectively. /Ciprofloxacin hydrochloride/

The Anatomical Therapeutic Chemical (ATC) Classification System is used for the classification of drugs. This pharmaceutical coding system divides drugs into different groups according to the organ or system on which they act and/or their therapeutic and chemical characteristics. Each bottom-level ATC code stands for a pharmaceutically used substance, or a combination of substances, in a single indication (or use). This means that one drug can have more than one code: acetylsalicylic acid (aspirin), for example, has A01AD05 as a drug for local oral treatment, B01AC06 as a platelet inhibitor, and N02BA01 as an analgesic and antipyretic. On the other hand, several different brands share the same code if they have the same active substance and indications.

Pharmacologic Class is a group of active moieties that share scientifically documented properties and is defined on the basis of any combination of three attributes of the active moiety: mechanism of action (MOA), physiologic effect (PE) and chemical structure (CS).  An FDA "Established Pharmacologic Class" (EPC) text phrase is a pharmacologic class associated with an approved indication of an active moiety that the FDA has determined to be scientifically valid and clinically meaningful.

Reference.Name: PFAS and Fluorinated Compounds in PubChem
Reference.Description:
The collection of per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) and other fluorinated compounds in PubChem as described in https://doi.org/10.1021/acs.est.3c04855. The 'OECD PFAS definition' (no salts) and 'PFAS breakdowns by chemistry' (with salts/mixtures) nodes contain PubChem content matching the OECD PFAS definition of saturated CF2 (Report ENV/CBC/MONO(2021)25). Other nodes explore 'organofluorine compounds'; 'other diverse fluorinated compounds'; 'PFAS and fluorinated compound collections' (including CompTox; NORMAN-SLE; NIST; OntoChem PFAS lists) and 'regulatory PFAS collections' (including Stockholm Convention/EU regulations for PFOS; PFOA; PFHxS; LC-PFCAs). Expand each node for more detailed content. Read more about this tree here: https://gitlab.com/uniluxembourg/lcsb/eci/pubchem-docs/-/raw/main/pfas-tree/PFAS_Tree.pdf?inline=false
Update: 2025-01-14 19:00:03

Reference.Name: EPA SRS List Classification
Reference.Description: Substance Registry Services (SRS) is the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) central system for information about substances that are tracked or regulated by EPA or other sources. It is a resource for basic information about chemicals, biological organisms, and other substances of interest to EPA and its state and tribal partners. SRS makes it possible to identify which EPA data systems, environmental statutes, or other sources have information about a substance and which synonym is used by that system or statute.

Reference.Name: MolGenie Organic Chemistry Ontology
Reference.Description: An organic chemistry ontology developed by MolGenie and OntoChem to assign chemical entities to structural classes, split into three main subsections: calculated properties, compounds and substructural concepts. The ontology contains chemistry structural classes with a focus on elements and small organic compounds, but not inorganic, polymer, biopolymer, metal complexes, metal organic frameworks (MOFs) and other chemistry entities. The ontology has been mapped to several collections of chemicals, including (a) Chemicals of Biological Interest (ChEBI), (b) the ChEMBL database of bioactive molecules, (c) the LOTUS natural product collection, (d) per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) extracted from Barnabas et al (2022) DOI: 10.1039/D2DD00019A (e) PubChemLite and (f) the ZeroPM Global Chemical Inventory.
